coredata.dc:title: Electric field dependence of charge carrier generation in alkane solutions of N,N,N',N'-tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine (TMPD)
coredata.dc:creator: S. Sethi, D
Choi, H.T.
Braun, C.L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Studies of the electric field dependence or photocurrents from solutions of TMPD in non-polar solvents are interpreted using Onsager's theory of geminate charge recombination. For all solvents and photon energies, a simple exponential form of the radial distribution function for geminate pairs accounts for the observed field dependence.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1980 Volume 74, number 2 ELECTRIC FIELD DEPENDENCE OF CHARGE CARRIER GENERATION CM ALKANE SOLUTIONS OF N,N,N',N'-TETRAMETHYL.p-PHENYLENEDIAMINE (TMPD) D S. SETHI *, H.T. CHOI ** and C.L. BRAUN Department of Chemistry. Dartmouth College, Hanover. New Hampshire 03755. USA Received 2 July 1980 Studies of the electric Held dependence of photocurrents from solutions of TMPD in non-polar solvents are interpreted using Onsager's theory of geminate charge recombination. For all solvents and photon energies, a simple exponential form of the radial distribution function for geminate pairs accounts for the observed field dependence. In most condensed phase materials, a photoionized electron comes to thermal equilibrium at a separation from its parent positive ion at which the ion's Coulomb field is still significant. At low ionization densities, the eventual fate of the thermalized election is either to recombine with its parent ion (geminate recombination) or to escape. Onsager [1] obtained an expression for the probability that a thermalized ion pair, diffusing in an appbed electric field, will escape geminate recom- bination. Onsager's theory has been successfully applied in numerous studies of condensed phase ionization in- cluding X-ray ionization of organic liquids [2—5], photoionization of amorphous solids [6,7} and of liquid solutions [8,9] and photoconductivity of an- thracene single crystals [10,11] . Here we apply the theory to studies of the electric field dependence of photocurrents from TMPD in three non-polar solvents- n-hexane (HEX), 2,2,4-tri-methylpentane (TMP), and tetramethylsilane (TMS). We report results of our in- vestigation of the best-fit form of the radial distribu- tion function of thermalized geminate pairs and of the function's dependence on excitation energy. The application of Onsager's theory to the photo- ionization process has been described in detail else- where [10,11]. The theory gives the geminate charge pair escape probability as a function of the initial Present address- Chemistry Department, University of Bridge- port, Bridgeport, Connecticut 06602, USA. Present address: Department of Chemistry, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota 55455, USA. separation r of the just-thennalized charge pair (thermali- zation length), the applied electric field strength E, the orientation of the charge pair with respect to E, and the temperature T. With the assumption that the thermalized charge pair distribution function is spherically symmetric and independent off, the escape probability for a sample of geminate pairs may be written as P(E, T, a) = N f P^(E, r, r)R(r, a) dr, (I) where Py is the angle-averaged Onsager escape probabili- ty and R(r, a) with range parameter a is the radial dis- tribution function of geminate pairs- /V" is a normaliza- tion constant determined such thatP-> 1 as£'-*-°°- Eq. (3c) of Mozumder [12] was used to compute the probability Py while the forms o[R(r, a) which are tested below are as follows: (i) Delta (DEL), R(r,Ro) =8(r- Ry), N = I. (ii) Narrow gaussian (N-GAUS), R(rJtf) = r2 X exp[-16(r - Af)2/Af2] ,N= 4/l^l/2Af3. (ui) Gaussian (pAVS),R(r,G) = r2 expC-r2/^2), N=4f^Tll2G3. (iv) Exponential (EXP), R(r, B) = exp(-r/B), N = \IB. GAUS2 and EXP3 have been used extensively in interpreting the X-ray induced conductivity of organic liquids while most photoconductivity studies [6,7,10, 11] have made use of the DEL function. The N-GAUS function has a theoretical basis in Sano and Mozumder's treatment [13] of the thennalization problem. 223 Volume 74, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1980 At constant temperature and excitation energy, photo- conduction quantum yields <S>(E) at field strength E are proportional to P(E) — hereafter P(E) replaces P(E,T,a) ofeq.(l) (2) where 0,, the quantum yield of thermalized charge pairs is assumed to be field independent. Under our ex- perimental conditions, the measured photocurrent ((£") is proportional to 0ff) and we may use eq. (2) to write (3) The experimental zero-field current ;(0) is determined by a short linear extrapolation of low field i(E) values to E = 0. Eq. (3) then allows comparison of experimental values of i(E)ls(0) with theoretical values ofP(E)/P(0). Such comparisons are illustrated for TMPD in HEX in Fig. 1 and for TMPD in TMS in fig. 2. While all four functional forms of R allow reasonable fits to the HEX data, EXP provides a superior fit (see Fig. 1). The dif- ferences are far more striking for the TMS curves of fig. 2. Best-fit P(E){P(0) curves determined using the DEL 4 8 IZ 16 E x ^"'•(V/m) a 12 ie E ilO-6!^!!) Fig. 2. As in fig. I but for TMPD/TMS solutions excited at 5.77eV. n Gnus .V'' 1S.S ,^'0 •9 .v ^'••^ '.', "S '• 50 PjE) P(01 (-^)'° e '2 8 E«10'' 12 (V/m) E«IO'°(V/m) Fig. 1. Comparison of electric field dependence of experimental TMPD/HEX phoiocuncnt ratios, :(E)fi(0) (points), with theo- retical escape probability ratios, P(E)fP(0) (solid lines), for four geminate pair distribution functions. Excitation energy = 7.08 eV. and N-GAUS functions have a far-stronger downward curvature than does the experimental curve. The broader GAUS function allows a somewhat better fit, but EXP provides a clearly superior fit to the data. EXP allows the best fits to the TMPD in TMP results of fig. 3 as well where best-fits to results for a number of excitation energies are presented. Note in fig. 3 the steady increase in length parameter B as the photon energy is increased. Figs 1—3 and similar results to be pubbshed else- where demonstrate that for all three solvents and for all photon energies (5—7 eV), (he EXP distribution function allows better fits to experimental field depen- dence data than do DEL, N-GAUS or GAUS. Generally the EXP fits are remarkably good for HEX (average deviation < 2%), good for TMP (^ 3%), and fair for TMS (^ 5%). As the functional form narrows in the order EXP, GAUS, N-GAUS, and DEL, the best-fits deviate more and more from experiment. Broad distribution functions like EXP and GAUS have been found to give better fits to data for X-ray ionized organic liquids than narrow functions like DEL and N-GAUS. Abel and Funabashi [4] concluded that EXP gave the best fits to the applied field dependence 224 Volume 74, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1980 Fig. 3. Electric field dependence ofphoiocurrent ratio idE)l t(0) at various excitation energies for TMPD/TMP solutions (points) compared with best-fit theoretical P(E)IP(0) values for EXP geminate pair distribution functions (lines) All curves actually intercept at unity but have been displaced from one another by one unit for purposes of clarity. The number above each curve is the excitation energy (eV) and the number below is the thennalization length parameter Z?(A). of X-ray induced currents in several abphatic liquids [14,15] as well as to the concentration dependence of free electron scavenging in the same liquids [16] . Mozumder [5] also concluded that EXP generally al- lowed the best fits to field dependence data for several neat organic liquids while a second look [17] at the electron scavenging data again showed that it was best fit by an exponential distribution of thennalization lengths. Dodelet et al. [18] have examined various dis- tribution functions in their X-ray excited conductivity studies. They excluded EXP from consideration, pre- ferring a gaussian function with a power function tail at large r (GP in their notation). GP yielded poor fits when tested against our data like those of figs. 1—3. X-ray experiments, however, suffer from a possible disadvantage compared to those employing low-energy photoionization in that multiple ionizations often take place in small volumes of X-ray excited liquids [3] (spurs and blobs). This means that Onsager's theory which applies to isolated, geminate pairs is not strictly applicable to the primary population of ionized pairs in X-inadiated liquids. Rapid bimolecular recombination within blobs of charge may lead to a surviving charge pair which is not geminate. Moreover X-irradiation in- volves a very large spectrum of excitation energies and thus potentially a wide array of thennalization lengths as compared to ionization with monochromatic low- energy photons. For these reasons, the fact that the EXP function gives best-fits to most X-irradiation data does not necessarily imply that the EXP distribution should obtain for low-energy photoionization. However, we find that based solely on the criterion of best fits to the field-dependence of our photocurrent data, the EXP distribution does work best. For other photoionization studies, the results are mixed. Bullot, Cordier and Gauthier (BCG) have studied electric-field induced fluorescence quenching in solutions ofTMPD in TMP and TMS [9] . Granted several reasonable assumptions, their results should be directly comparable with ours. They find that GAUS and a truncated exponential can be used to fit their data equally well while narrower dis- tributions give poor fits. The inability of BCG to dis- criminate between GAUS and the exponential form results from the narrower field range of those results [(0—6) X 106 V/m] as compared to the maximum field of 18 X 106 V/m reached in the present work. The numerical thermahzation parameters of BCG agree quite well with our own. Most recent field-dependent photo- conductivity studies on solids have been interpreted using the DEL distribution function [6,7,10,11] and this does not seem to have been merely a matter of con- venience. Our attempts to fit the amorphous Se data of Pai and Enck [6] and the polymeric photoconduc- tivity data of Borsenberger [7] using the EXP distribu- tion were not successful. Thus broad distributions seem to be characteristic of electron thennalization in alkane liquids irrespective of the mode of ionization while a narrow distribution (DEL) is required in several amor- phous solids. It would be surprising if the obvious dif- ferences between liquid and solid phases were relevant to the distribution function width. Even though one might wish for data on more sys- tems before speculating on why such an apparent quali- tative difference should exist, the high quasi-free elec- tron mobilities of alkane liquids as compared with electron mobilities in the amorphous solids are a notable difference between the two classes of materials. The electron mobility in TMS is near 100 cm^fV s and the pre-exponential factors in the temperature-activated drift mobdities observed in TMP and HEX are similarly 225 Volume 74, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1980 large [19]. The drift mobilities actually measured in TMP and HEX are much lower but those values may be irrelevant to geminate recombination which occurs on a picosecond or shorter time scale [20]. High mobili- ties are associated with long scattering lengths for mo- mentum transfer (=s 70 A. in TMS [19]) and suggest the possibility that the classical-mechanical view of electron thennalization which leads to a narrow distribution [13] (N-GAUS) is inadequate. As first discussed by Abell and Funabashi [4], the EXP distribution arises naturally if the photoionized electron is regarded as an outgoing spherical wave with an electron thennalization probabil- ity that is independent of cation— electron separation. Another view which also leads to an exponential dis- tribution function in a natural way is to imagine that in the alkane liquids, thermalization proceeds through a succession of Wanmer exciton states each with a proba- bility density that decays exponentially away from the origin. Either of the above quantum-mechanical pic- tures might be relevant in the alkanes where weak elec- tron scattering excludes a classical-mechanical view [13] of electron thennalization. However, substantial caution is called for in inferring from the present results that the thermalized charge distribution is in fact exponential. Three important as- sumptions none of which have been tested at the high fields employed in this work are embodied in the simple form ofeqs. (l)—(3).R(r.a) is unlikely to be indepen- dent of applied field as assumed. For example at r = 100 A, a characteristic thennalization length in TMS, the Coulomb Field is a bit less than half of the maximum applied field used in this work. It is also possible that <^ might not be independent of applied Held as assumed. Finally in all three solvents, the electron mobility is known to be field dependent [19]. Thus the propor- tionality between the negative charge mobility and dif- fusion constant which is implicit in the use of Onsager's theory for the calculation ofP,. is not ensured. Unfor- tunately there is no clear substitute for Onsager's theory in the present case of field-dependent mobilities [21]. Aldnch 99% purity TMPD was purified by recrystal- lization from hexane followed by double-zone refining. Phulips research grade (99.99% purity) TMP and HEX were first dried by passage through a silica-gel column. Further purification of all three solvents as well as TMPD solution preparation and filling of the photoconduction cell was earned out under high vacuum (< 10~6 Ton). Solvent purification involved the following steps: (1) 3 or 4 freeze—pump—thaw cycles, (2) contact with degassed molecular sieves for one day or more, and (3) prolonged contact with a freshly evaporated Ba film C> 48 h). The final solutions (TMPD concentration »s2 X 10~3 M) typically exhibited quasi-free electron lifetimes of 1 JUS or greater. The photoconductivity cell was designed for mea- surements at high electric fields. One electrode is a semi-transparent, Ta metal-coated quartz substrate which transmits the excitation. The back electrode, machined from a steel gauge block is positioned by a spring. The spacing between the electrodes is determined by a quartz spacer (»s 0.2 mm thick) which is sandwiched between the two electrodes by the force of the spring. Photocunents (=» 10~11 A) were measured either by an electrometer (Keithley model 615) or a lock-in amplifier (Princeton Applied Research model 5101) with a mechanical light chopper (104 Hz). A 45 W deuterium lamp was used for excitation at wavelengths above 200 nm and a microwave excited xenon discharge was used at shorter wavelengths. A Minuteman VUV monochro- mator provided excitation with a spectral band pass of 5 nm. Measurements were carried out at room tempera- ture which ranged from 23—27°C. A more complete account of our field dependence work including absolute measurements of 0(£) at low fields will be published elsewhere. V/e wish to acknowledge support of this work by NSF grant DMR 77-00318 and to thank Dan Saucy for help in the computation ofP(E). References [1] L Onsager, Phys. Rev. 54 (1938) 55A. [2] G.R. Further purification of all three solvents as well as TMPD solution preparation and filling of the photoconduction cell was earned out under high vacuum (< 10~6 Ton). ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Studies of the electric field dependence or photocurrents from solutions of TMPD in non-polar solvents are interpreted using Onsager's theory of geminate charge recombination. For all solvents and photon energies, a simple exponential form of the radial distribution function for geminate pairs accounts for the observed field dependence.
